title: 112_hr3119
content: The Act titled "Protecting American Families and Businesses Act of 2011" ensures equal treatment among foreign states. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to impose numerical limitations on visas to any single foreign state. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the application of visa regulations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to impose numerical limitations on visas to any single foreign state. Special rules are established for countries at the visa ceiling to allocate visa numbers in a proportional manner. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to impose numerical limitations on visas to any single foreign state, with special rules for countries at the visa ceiling to allocate visa numbers proportionally. Amendments made under section 203(a) include country-specific offsets and transition rules for employment-based immigrants starting from fiscal year 2013. For fiscal year 2014, a portion of immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allocated to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of lawful permanent residents in the previous fiscal year. For fiscal year 2015, 10 percent of immigrant visas under section 203(b) will be allotted to natives of foreign states not among the top two states with the highest number of lawful permanent residents in the previous fiscal year. Per-country visa levels restrict the number of visas for any single foreign state to 25. For fiscal years 2013, 2014, and 2015, a maximum of 25 percent of immigrant visas can be allotted to natives of any single foreign state under section 203(b). Additionally, unreserved visas will be allocated based on specific calculations for each fiscal year. The number of immigrant visas available for a fiscal year is 70% of the total visas under section 203(b). Rules for chargeability apply to determine the foreign state an alien is chargeable to. SEC. 3. SPECIAL PROVISIONS IN CASES OF LENGTHY ADJUDICATIONS. Special provisions in cases of lengthy adjudications for employment-based immigrants allow for an extension of authorized stay if 365 days have passed since filing certain applications or petitions. The Secretary of Homeland Security can extend the stay of an alien who qualifies for an extension under certain visa categories until a final decision is made on their application or petition. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to provide dual intent for students and make conforming amendments to certain sections. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include dual intent for students and make adjustments to various sections related to family-based immigrants. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow dual intent for students and make adjustments to family-based immigrant visa availability. SEC. 4. RECAPTURING IMMIGRANT VISAS LOST TO BUREAUCRATIC DELAY. Section 201(d) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to set the worldwide level of employment-based immigrants for a fiscal year at 140,000, plus additional numbers based on previous fiscal year visa issuances and unused visas. The Immigration and Nationality Act sets the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants and employment-based immigrants for a fiscal year. Unused visas are calculated based on the difference between the established levels and the number of visas actually issued. The Immigration and Nationality Act establishes the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants, with a minimum threshold of 226,000. The number of visas issued is calculated based on various factors outlined in the Act. The number of immigrant visas issued in a fiscal year is determined by the difference between the maximum number of visas allowed for employment-based immigrants and the actual number issued. Unused visas are also taken into account in this calculation. The number of immigrant visas issued is based on the maximum allowed visas for employment-based immigrants and the actual number issued. Unused visas are also considered in this calculation. The sum of worldwide visa levels established for fiscal years 1992-2011 and the number of visas actually issued during those years, as well as the number of visas issued after 2011, are important factors.
